metadata.title: Painting Animation Documentation
metadata.subtitle: A Resource for Artists Exploring Hand-Painted Animation
metadata.author: Sura Karnawi
metadata.description: Comprehensive guide to painting animation techniques, materials, process, and interactive applications

content.text: Painting animation is the art of capturing one painting transforming into another through stop-motion technique. Unlike traditional animation where you draw each frame separately, painting animation involves continuously altering a single surface—painting over what you just created, capturing it, then painting again. It's an ephemeral medium where each frame exists only briefly before being transformed into the next.

I discovered this medium while creating Unleaving, a video game supported by Telefilm Canada. Over three years, I created thousands of paintings and conducted more than 22,000 scans for landscapes and background scenes. But it was a single moment—scanning a floating leaf on glass against a blank background, then watching it drift through the game world—that changed everything. That's when I fell in love with painting animation.

What draws me to this medium is its capacity for emotional storytelling. Hand-painted frames carry a warmth and humanity that's different from digital animation. There's something about seeing brush strokes, watching paint blend and transform, that creates an intimate connection with viewers. It's not just about making things look beautiful—it's about making people feel.

When I started exploring painting animation beyond Unleaving, I found very little documentation available. I reached out to Canadian film productions and discovered that even master animators like Aleksandr Petrov (who created 'The Old Man and the Sea') noted this gap. This site exists to share what I've learned, to make the medium more accessible, and to compile resources for anyone interested in this craft.

items: Address the lack of documentation in painting animation
Create a learning resource for beginners and advanced practitioners
Compile resources and discoveries
Showcase the emotional impact of the medium

content.text: Surfaces: What to Paint On

rows.advantages: Light passes through, creating luminous quality; can stack multiple layers; easy to wipe clean between frames
rows.challenges: Reflective surface requires careful lighting; paint can be slippery; work is completely ephemeral

rows.advantages: Familiar surface for painters; paint adheres well
rows.challenges: Can't stack layers; harder to clean between frames; texture visible in scans
Limited to single-layer work; can wrinkle or absorb paint unevenly

content.text: My recommendation: Start with glass. Yes, it's challenging, but the results are worth it.
Water-Mixable Oils (My Choice)

items: Working time: 15-30 minutes before drying
Perfect for: Smooth transitions, blending colors
Cost: Moderate
Health: Better than traditional oils, but work in ventilated space

content.title: Carine Khalife's Secret
content.text: Mix oil paint half-and-half with generic grease. It keeps paint workable for days and smells better than turpentine.
Traditional Acrylics

items: Working time: Less than 5 minutes
Perfect for: Quick sequences, bold color changes
Challenge: Dries too fast for detailed work

content.text: Traditional Oils

items: Working time: 2+ hours
Perfect for: Complex, layered work
Challenge: Strong fumes, requires proper ventilation, long drying time

content.title: Health Note
content.text: I discovered the hard way that oil paint fumes can cause breathing issues. After two weeks of coughing from oil painting sessions, I switched to water-mixable oils and improved my ventilation. Don't skip this.
Essential Setup

items: Dedicated table (don't move it between sessions—consistency is crucial)
Light source: Either overhead or beneath (lightbox)
Black box or controlled environment for consistent lighting
Camera mounted on stable arm OR overhead scanner
Tape to mark painting boundaries (keeps capture area consistent)

content.text: Light Source Options

items.title: Overhead Light
pros: Easy to see what you're doing
cons: Requires diffusion to avoid hot spots and glare

items.title: Lightbox (Beneath Glass)
cons: Harder to see what you're painting
items.note: Carine Khalife uses this method and paints at night for ultimate control

content.title: Pro Tip
content.text: Whatever you choose, keep your light source CONSTANT. Any variation will show in your final animation.
Camera Setup

items: Mount camera directly above painting surface
Connect to computer for immediate preview
No flash—use consistent continuous lighting
Position in dark or controlled-light room to avoid reflections

content.text: Scanner (My Unleaving Experience)

items: Limited to A3 size
LED scanners are more color-accurate than CCFL
Only works with matte, non-reflective surfaces
Can't use with glass effectively

content.text: Scanner vs. Camera: I started with an overhead scanner for Unleaving but hit limitations. For glass work and larger pieces, a camera setup is essential.
Why It Matters
DragonFrame is the industry standard, and for good reason. It shows you 50% of your previous frame overlaid on your current view (onion skinning). This is game-changing.
Key Features

items: See your previous frame while painting the next
Scrub through your sequence while working
Adjust timing and pacing in real-time
Export frames for editing

content.text: You must feel the movement, not only have a nice picture. It's like a singer singing—they can't stop the voice at some point. You need to see the sequence while painting.
content.author: Carine Khalife

content.text: Storyboarding Without Over-Planning
I used to think I needed detailed storyboards. I was wrong.
What Works

items: Clean a wall
Use Post-it notes with feeling words: 'picking up a wave,' 'small wave,' 'big wave,' 'skies'
Identify key frames (important moments)
Note transformation moments (where one thing becomes another)
That's your timeline

content.text: If I put expectations too high and I don't get there, I feel disappointed. I only control what I want people to feel—dark, strong, small. Then I make some sketches. I think about it, then I let it go.
content.author: Carine Khalife

content.text: The Philosophy: Aim for a destination, not a detailed map. Leave room for the magic that happens when you surrender to the process.
For Transformation Sequences

items: Use 2-3 colors maximum
Choose high contrast
Focus on shapes, not detailed representation
Keep dark/light values consistent to avoid distraction

content.text: Inspiration Sources I Use

items: NASA telescope images for cosmic palettes
Carine Khalife's work for emotional color
Kim Keever's underwater photography for atmospheric feeling
Natural phenomena (I painted water, roots, cosmic scenes)

content.text: My Process: I keep key reference images visible while painting. When stuck, I look at them for feeling, not for copying.
The First Frame Challenge
Every artist struggles with the first frame. It's the hardest.
What Helps

items: Read something to get into the feeling you want to capture
Look at references (but for emotion, not detail)
Accept it might take 3-4 days just for that first frame
Remember: Once you start, subsequent frames get easier

content.text: My Experience: When I returned to painting after working as a developer, I lost creative energy. Solution? Look at inspiration constantly. I found Evgenia Gostrer's work, and just looking at it while sketching stirred my creativity again.

items: Paint the frame
Check it against previous frame (onion skin in DragonFrame)
Capture the image
Scrub through sequence to check movement
Paint over for next frame
Repeat

content.text: Timing: I aim for 8 frames per second. Each transformation moment takes about 12 frames (1.5 seconds).
The Rhythm: Don't think too much between frames. Feel the movement. Carine paints at night specifically because she enters a flow state where conscious control gives way to intuitive movement.

subsections.title: Working with Glass Layers (3D Sandwich Technique)

content.text: For depth effects, I paint on multiple glass sheets stacked with spacers between them:
Applications

items: Ears, hearts, tunnels (3D objects in my Inception project)
Foreground/background separation
Parallax effects when captured

content.text: Technique: Paint different elements on each layer, stack them, capture together. Move layers slightly between frames for depth.
Inspired by: Aleksandr Petrov's 'The Old Man and the Sea' and Yuri Norstein's multi-plane glass technique.

items.title: The Tape Trick
items.description: Use tape to mark your painting boundaries. This ensures your capture area stays identical across all frames.

items.title: Color Consistency
items.description: Mix enough paint for the entire sequence. Running out mid-sequence and trying to remix the exact color is nearly impossible.

items.title: Lighting Check
items.description: Before starting, capture a blank frame. Check it against your first frame hours later. If the lighting shifted, you'll see it.

content.text: Cultivating Focus
Painting animation requires intense concentration. Glass work especially—once it's painted over, it's gone forever.
Carine Khalife's Approach

items: Paints at night when the world is quiet
Works on a lightbox (only she sees the true glowing painting)
By morning, everything is painted over
'It feels like a dream'

content.text: The Humility Practice
You can't be precious about your work. Each beautiful frame you paint will be destroyed to create the next. This teaches letting go.
The creative process in painting animation is about surrender.
What This Means

items: Plan the feeling, not every detail
Let the paint guide you
Accept that 'perfect' doesn't serve the story
Meet yourself halfway between your highest expectations and reality

content.text: Perfection isn't interesting. It can be nice, well done, but how does it feel looking at it? It may not move you or make you feel anything.
content.author: Carine Khalife

content.text: My Learning: When I tried to control everything in early experiments, the work felt stiff. When I focused on capturing a feeling and let the medium do what it wanted, magic happened.
Finding Inspiration

items: Look at other artists' work (not to copy, but to feel)
Watch transformation animations (Evgenia Gostrer, Julia Gromskaya)
Go outside, observe nature
Talk to your mentor or support person
Read something that captures the emotion you want

content.text: My Ritual: When I hit a wall, I spend time looking at Carine Khalife's 'Womb Stories,' Kim Keever's underwater photography, and NASA images. I don't analyze them—I just let them stir something in me.

subsections.title: Interview with Carine Khalife
subsections.subtitle: Lebanese painting animator, creator of 'Womb Stories'

quotes.text: I have worked with many mediums, but my favorite is oil on glass. It allows me to capture the feeling of strong, strange movement that I like to create.
quotes.context: Her secret? Mix oil paint half-and-half with grease. It keeps paint workable for days and smells better than turpentine.

quotes.text: I like painting on glass. It's strange because you lose it. You have to be humble. You can't be proud because in the morning, the painting is gone.
quotes.context: She paints at night on a lightbox. She's the only person who sees the work in its true, glowing form. 'I think what people see [in the final video] is only 10% of the magic.'

quotes.text: When the sun comes up, I have coffee and go to bed. It feels like it was all a dream.
Painting on glass is really difficult. You have to be really focused because it's not like pencil and paper where you can redo it or change it. Once it's gone, it's gone.
quotes.context: The first frame takes her 3-4 days. After that, she finds her rhythm.

quotes.text: It's more a feeling I'm looking for rather than a reference or a book. I want to understand how to make people feel in order to capture it.
quotes.context: Her process: Read until she finds the feeling → Go to the studio → If it doesn't work, go back and try again → 'It's always difficult, but when I know what feeling to capture, it becomes easier'

quotes.text: If I put expectations too high and I don't get there, I feel disappointed. I only control what I want people to feel—dark, strong, small. Then I make some sketches. I think about it, then I let it go. It works!
quotes.context: Her storyboarding: Post-it notes on a wall with feeling words, not detailed drawings.

quotes.text: Perfection isn't possible. It takes too much time, and in the end, it may not capture the feelings. It's not too interesting.

items: Lightbox: Paint becomes darker the more layers you add
Dark room: No daylight, only constant artificial light
Camera: Mounted above, connected to computer
DragonFrame: Shows 50% of previous frame

content.text: You must feel the movement, not only have a nice picture. It's like a singer singing—they can't stop the voice at some point. You need to keep singing and stop when it feels convenient to convey a rhythm.

subsections.title: Beyond Traditional Animation: Painting in Interactive Experiences

content.text: Traditional animation is linear—you watch it from beginning to end. But what if viewers could participate in the unfolding of a painted story?
Why Interactive?

Hand-painted animation has emotional warmth. Interactive experiences create agency and connection. Combined, they offer something unique: the intimacy of painting with the engagement of participation.

subsections.title: My Journey: From Unleaving to Inception

content.name: Unleaving (2024)
content.description: In this video game, I used glass painting animation for environmental storytelling. Players explore landscapes where:
features: Painted leaves float and react to player movement
Seasonal transitions unfold through painted transformation sequences
Background environments shift as players progress
content.insight: That floating leaf on glass—extracted and integrated into the game—taught me that painted elements in interactive spaces feel alive in ways digital assets don't.

content.name: Inception (Current Project)
content.description: A 2.5D point-and-click experience exploring fetal development and interconnectedness. Players interact with:
features: Transformation moments: Click on organs (heart, ear, eye) to trigger hand-painted sequences
3D glass layers: Multiple painted layers create depth when players zoom in/out
Emotional arc: Nurture a developing life, then discover you have no control over where it's born
content.insight: Interactivity amplifies painting animation's emotional impact. When viewers trigger a transformation themselves, they become part of the creation.

content.text: Pipeline

items: Paint animation sequences frame-by-frame
Capture in DragonFrame
Export frame sequences
Import into Unity as sprite sheets
Code interactive triggers (clicks, hovers, drags)
Add 3D layering for depth

content.text: Example from Inception

items: Player sees a bean-like form floating in cosmic space
Click triggers 12-frame transformation: bean → roots → tunnel
Camera zooms through tunnel (3D painted layers create parallax)
Player encounters sperm swimming sequence
Shake mouse to help sperm reach egg
Inception moment: painted cells multiply and transform

content.text: The Effect: Each interaction feels personal, intentional. Players aren't just watching development unfold—they're participating in creation.

items.challenge: Painted frames can feel static when simply triggered
items.solution: Use transformation moments for interactions. Make the paint respond to player input.

items.challenge: Balancing artistic vision with player control
items.solution: Create an emotional arc where player agency leads to a predetermined feeling (in Inception: the illusion of choice, the reality that we don't control where we're born).
Optimize frame sequences, use strategic 3D layering instead of full animation for every element.

Inspiration Sources
Finding Mentors

content.text: Reaching Out
When I needed help, I emailed artists directly:

items: Carine Khalife (responded and gave amazing interview)
Patrick Jenkins (Toronto-based glass animator)
Laura (Laurimation, shared technical tips)

content.text: Don't be afraid to ask. Most artists remember when they were learning and want to help.
Painting animation isn't about perfection. It's about capturing feeling in the most ephemeral way possible.
Every frame you paint will be destroyed to create the next. This isn't tragic—it's liberating. You learn to work with urgency, to trust your instincts, to let go.
The medium demands humility. Your most beautiful frame exists for seconds before you paint over it. Only you see it in its true form. By morning, it's gone.
But that ephemeral magic? The 10% that makes it to the final video? That's enough. That's everything.
Start simple

items: One sheet of glass
Two colors
One feeling you want to capture
12 frames

content.text: That's enough for your first transformation.
Remember

items: The first frame takes forever. That's normal.
Perfect frames don't make perfect animation. Movement makes perfect animation.
Read Carine Khalife's advice again when you're stuck
Find your support person
Document your process (you'll want to remember)

content.text: Most importantly: Don't wait for the perfect setup. Start with what you have. The magic isn't in the equipment—it's in your willingness to paint something beautiful and then destroy it to create what comes next.
This documentation exists to share what I've learned. But the real magic happens when you see painting animation in action.
